name: nytimes
text:
RT @alanfeuer: NEW: It's been quite a week for long-awaited New York police reform.
First, the repeal of 50-A.
Then, the demise of the NYPD's anti-crime unit.
Today, the City Council passed the POST Act which enforces transparency on NYPD's vast surveillance apparatus. 
https://t.co/5uWULSFP7n

In Opinion

name: nytimes
text: Today is Juneteenth. It is a celebration of freedom long in the making. Its history is illuminating and inspiring. “The essential message is the connection, renewal and joy for a people who have had to endure so much, for so long,” @vvchambers writes. https://t.co/dttPTaStln

name: nytimes
text:
Juneteenth marks the day in 1865 that Union soldiers arrived in Galveston, Texas, to announce that the Civil War had ended and that enslaved African-Americans were free.

Here is what you should know about its history.
https://t.co/qD5lbcxGoo

name: nytimes
text: Some Americans celebrate Juneteenth at a cookout with loved ones. For others, it’s shopping only at black-owned businesses, sharing history or resting at home. “It’s more than celebrating the holiday. It’s celebrating life and the existence of life.” https://t.co/jh1jTPLWav

name: nytimes
text: The 93-year-old activist Opal Lee campaigned for years to have Juneteenth recognized as a U.S. holiday. As Black Lives Matter protests continue and many companies have made June 19 a paid day off, her vision is closer than ever to its realization. https://t.co/2vLlx7IqPb

name: nytimes
text: "I think we cannot go forward until we have a deeper, truer understanding of our past," said Susan Anderson, an expert on black history in California. She spoke to @JillCowan about the roots of Juneteenth and what we should learn from this moment. https://t.co/EvaadJA5Pp

name: nytimes
text: More elected officials and candidates for office are making reparations part of their political platforms a year after a first-of-its-kind Congressional hearing on reparations and more than 150 years after the end of slavery. https://t.co/ok6BiE1vyq

name: nytimes
text: A new generation of healers are embracing therapeutic techniques to help process the trauma black people have endured since the first enslaved people were brought to America in 1619.  “Rest is resistance, it’s reparations,” Tricia Hersey said. https://t.co/TaD68LLJHZ

name: nytimes
text: Understanding power and privilege requires education, and sometimes re-education. Rachel Elizabeth Cargle’s honest and empathic approach to changing white people and supporting black people is shifting perspectives on an increasingly large scale. https://t.co/kFDXOWLq3i
